ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Comparative literature skills. Translation nuances. Unique ways of structuring fiction. New favorite author!
I was able to read the major novels of one of the most important literary figures in Brazilian history.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths are the readings and discussion section. Readings you will get lost in, and Craig brought fantastic ideas to build on in discussion. Weakness is confusion about seminar vs lecture. KDJ gives a lecture in this class, and while these are very freeform, the students don't talk.

The material is amazing  these are some of the most fascinating, thorny, beautiful books I've read in a long time. And Professor Jackson, aside from his obvious (and remarkable) expertise in all things Machado, clearly cares deeply about the novels.

The course often took the form of a seminar-sized lecture, so I did wonder about the need for the optional section held on Wednesday mornings. I felt that there could have been more explicit opportunities for participation/exchange in the classroom itself. Mostly, though, I feel lucky to have been in this course, and to have gotten the chance to engage with these texts  and with Professor Jackson's knowledge of them.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if they are able to pay attention to a two hour lecture. Content is fascinating, and KDJ does have vast knowledge.

Anyone interested in Brazilian literature can benefit from this course. Be advised that there is a lot of reading. It pretty much starts and doesn't stop, and you're reading at least 100/200 pages per week (which is a lot, especially if you're trying to work with the original texts in Portuguese). But, at least in my mind, it's very much worth it.

extras.title: LITR 290 01/PORT 353 01/PORT 967 01 - Machado de Assis: Major Novels
